bibl.title: Statement by Walter Reed concerning Jesse W. Lazear, January 11, 1902

div1.p: Reed praises the service of Lazear and insists he died in the line of duty.

div1.head: Statement by Walter Reed concerning Jesse W. Lazear, January 11, 1902
div1.p:
As senior member of the Board of Medical Officers convened by Special
Orders, No. 122, Adjutant General's Office, Washington, May 24th, 1900,
for the scientific investigation of yellow fever on the Island of Cuba,
I cannot speak too highly of the services of the late Dr. Jesse W. Lazear,
Acting Assistant Surgeon, U.S.A.

As a member of this Board he displayed at all times an enthusiastic
and fearless devotion to duty which was worthy of the highest commenda-
tion. He repeatedly risked his life by entering houses that were badly
infected with yellow fever, in order that he might gain, if possible,
some knowledge of the spread of this disease: and later when it became
desirable to test the transmission of the disease by means of the bite
of infected mosquitoes, Dr. Lazear unhesitatingly offered himself for
the experiment. In thus voluntarily sacrificing his life he had no other
object in view than the good that might thereby come to his fellow-man.
Although holding no commission in the Regular Army, Dr. Lazear, in my
opinion, died as plainly in the line of duty as any officer or soldier
who has ever fallen in battle.
div1.closer:
Walter Reed,
Major & Surgeon, U.S.A.
President of the Board. Washington, D.C.
January 11, 1902.
